issues.description: The template's singFarmSongVerse method is declared without an Animal parameter (it has a commented placeholder /*Animal animal*/), while the problem UML and the solution implementation expect singFarmSongVerse(Animal animal). This parameter mismatch means students following the template will find the helper method signature inconsistent with the UML and reference solution and may be confused about how to pass the current animal into the verse-printing logic.
issues.suggested_fix: Update the template Farm.java helper signature to accept an Animal parameter as specified in the UML and used by the solution. For example: private void singFarmSongVerse(Animal animal) { ... } and then use the passed animal in the method body (animal.getClass().getSimpleName(), animal.messageOnFeed(), etc.).

issues.description: The UML (problem statement) and the template define singFarmSongVerse as a private helper method, but the reference solution declares it as protected. This visibility mismatch across artifacts could confuse students about the intended accessibility of the helper method.
issues.suggested_fix: Make the visibility consistent across artifacts. Prefer matching the UML/template by changing the solution method to private (private void singFarmSongVerse(Animal animal)) or, if protected is intentional, update the UML and template to declare it protected. Choose one visibility and apply it to both template and solution to avoid student confusion.
